newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel's Weizman cut ties with Netanyahu -paper.
newsitem.headline: Israel's Weizman cut ties with Netanyahu -paper.

text.p: Israeli President Ezer Weizman was quoted by an Israeli newspaper on Friday as saying he had cut off contact with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over his attitude towards a peacemaking crisis with the Palestinians.
"I have cut all contact with him. Bibi isn't ready to listen. He knows everything," the daily Yedioth Ahronoth quoted Weizman, using Netanyahu's nickname, as saying.
"When I returned from the meeting with (Palestinian President Yasser) Arafat, I thought he would want to hear what happened there. Not at all."
Netanyahu's spokesman, Shai Bazak, said of the report: "As far as I know that isn't true." Weizman's spokesman was not available to comment.
Weizman, whose post is largely ceremonial, is well-known in Israel for bluntness. He met Arafat 10 days ago in an effort to overcome a two-month impasse in Israel-PLO peace talks.
On May 12, Weizman told Israel Television: "I see myself as the icebreaker. I opened the channel and the convoy needed to follow it...but the convoy did not follow it."
"More desire is needed, a lot more desire and a lot more understanding. I opened the channel, I hope. Anyone who wants can travel down it...."
Peacemaking ground to a halt when Netanyahu ordered work to begin on a new Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem on March 18.
Netanyahu this week said he was proud of the decision to build the 6,500-unit settlement.

Israel insists the eastern part of the city it captured from Jordan in 1967 will remain its eternal, united capital. The Palestinians want East Jerusalem as capital of a future state. They say settlement-building pre-empts final peace talks.
Yedioth, quoting minutes of the Weizman-Arafat meeting the newspaper said it obtained, said Weizman brought Arafat a compromise proposal from Netanyahu.
"You start building first, massively, at Har Homa," the newspaper quoted Weizman as saying. Israel calls the settlement site Har Homa. Palestinians call it Jabal Abu Ghneim.
"Prime Minister Netanyahu agrees you build between five and 10,000 houising units for young (Arab) couples from East Jerusalem, with aid and government funding from Israel."
Yedioth said Arafat rejected the proposal.
Netanyahu's spokesman denied there was such a proposal.
On Friday, U.S. Middle East peace envoy Dennis Ross was due to leave the region after coming up empty in a bid to bring the sides back to the negotiating table.
